<title type="main">The first epistle of the first book of Horace imitated</title>

EPISTLES OF HORACE. BOOK I. EPISTLE I. Prima dicte mihi, summâ dicende Camenâ! S?? whose love indulg'd my labours past, Matures my present, and shall bound my last! Why Spectatum satis, & donatum jam rude, quæris (Mæcenas) iterum antiquo me includere ludo? Non eadem est ætas, non mens.will you break the Sabbath of my days? Now sick alike of Envy and of Praise. Publick too long, ah let me hide my Age! See modest Vejanius ArmisCibber now has left the Stage: Our Gen'rals now, Herculis ad postem fixis, latet abditus agro, Ne populumretir'd to their Estates, Hang their old Trophies o'er the Garden gates, In Life's cool evening satiate of applause, Nor extremâ, toties, exoret arenâ.fond of bleeding, ev'n in Br?'s cause. Est mihi, purgatam crebro qui personet aurem; “SolveA Voice there is, that whispers in my ear, ('Tis Reason's voice, which sometimes one can hear) “Friend Pope! be prudent, let your senescentem mature sanus equum, ne “Peccet ad extremum ridendus, & ilia ducat.” Nunc itaque, &Muse take breath, “And never gallop Pegasus to death; “Lest stiff, and stately, void of fire, and force, “You limp, like Blackmore, on a Lord Mayor's horse.’ Farewell then Versus & cætera ludicra pono, QuidVerse, and Love, and ev'ry Toy, The rhymes and rattles of the Man or Boy: What verum atque decens, curo & rogo, & omnis in hoc sum.right, what true, what fit, we justly call, Let this be all my care—for this is All: To lay this Condo & compono quæ mox depromere possim. Ac ne forte roges,harvest up, and hoard with haste What ev'ry day will want, and most, the last. But ask not, to what quo me duce, quo Lare tuter? Nullius addictus jurare in verba Magistri,Doctors I apply? Sworn to no Master, of no Sect am I: As drives the Quo me cunque rapit tempestas, deferor Hospes. Nunc agilis fio, & mersorstorm, at any door I knock, And house with Montagne now, or now with Lock. Sometimes a civilibus undis, Virtutis veræ Custos,Patriot, active in debate, Mix with the World, and battle for the State, Free as young Lyttelton, her cause pursue, Still true to Virtue, rigidusque satelles.Nunc in Omnis Aristippum decuit color, & status, & res.Aristippi and as warm as true: Sometimes, with Aristippus, or St. Paul, Indulge my Candor, and grow all to all; Back to my furtim præcepta relabor Et mihi res, non me rebus, submittere conor.native Moderation slide, And win my way by yielding to the tyde. Ut nox longa quibus mentitur amica, diesque Longa videtur opus debentibus, ut piger annus Pupillis, quos dura premit custodia matrum: Sic mihi tardaLong, as to him who works for debt, the Day; Long as the Night to her whose love's away; Long as the Year's dull circle seems to run, When the brisk Minor pants for twenty-one; So slow th' fluunt ingrataque tempora, quæ spem Consiliumque morantur agendi gnaviterunprofitable Moments roll, That lock up all the Functions of my soul; That keep me from Myself; and still delay Life's instant business to a future day: That id, quod Æque pauperibus prodest, locupletibus æque, Æque neglectum pueris, senibusque nocebit.task, which as we follow, or despise, The eldest is a fool, the youngest wise; Which done, the poorest can no wants endure, And which not done, the richest must be poor. Restat, ut his ego me ipse regam,Late as it is, I put my self to school, And feel some solerque, Elementis.comfort, not to be a fool. Non possis oculo quantum contendere Lynceus, Non tamen idcirco contemnas lippus inungi: Nec, quia desperes invicti membra Glyconis, Nodosâ corpus nolis prohibere chiragrâ. Est quâdam prodireWeak tho' I am of limb, and short of sight, Far from a Lynx, and not a Giant quite, I'll do what Mead and Cheselden advise, To keep these limbs, and to preserve these eyes. Not to tenus, si non datur ultra.go back, is somewhat to advance, And men must walk at least before they dance. Say, does thy Fervet Avaritia, miseroque Cupidine pectus? Sunt verba & voces, quibus hunc lenire dolorem Possis, &blood rebel, thy bosom move With wretched Av'rice, or as wretched Love? Know, there are Words, and Spells, which can controll (magnam morbi deponere partem. Laudis amore tumes? suntBetween the Fits) this Fever of the soul: Know, there are Rhymes, which (certa piacula, quæ te Ter pure lecto poterunt recreare libello.fresh and fresh apply'd) Will cure the arrant'st Puppy of his Pride. Be Invidus, iracundus, iners, vinosus,furious, envious, slothful, mad or drunk, Amator, NemoSlave to a Wife or Vassal to a Punk, A Switz, a High-dutch, or a Low-dutch adeo ferus est ut non mitescere possit, Si modo culturæ patientem commodet aurem.Bear— All that we ask is but a patient Ear. Virtus est vitium fugere, & Sapientia prima Stultitia caruisse ? ? Vides, quæ'Tis the first Virtue, Vices to abhor; And the first Wisdom, to be Fool no more. But to the world, no maxima credis Esse mala, exiguum censum, turpemque repulsam, Quanto devites animi, capitisque labore? Impiger extremos curris mercator ad Indos, Perbugbear is so great, As want of figure, and a small Estate. To either India see the Merchant fly, Scar'd at the spectre of pale Poverty! See him, with pains of body, pangs of soul, mare pauperiem fugiens, per saxa, per ignes: Ne curesBurn through the Tropic, freeze beneath the Pole! Wilt thou do nothing for a nobler end, Nothing, to make Philosophy thy friend? To stop thy foolish views, thy long desires, And ea que stulte miraris & optas Discere, & audire, & meliori credere non vis?ease thy heart of all that it admires? Here, Wisdom calls: “Vilius argentum est auro, virtutibus aurum—“Seek Virtue first! be bold! “As Gold to Silver, Virtue is to Gold.” There, London's voice: “O cives, cives! quærenda Pecunia primum est, “Virtus post nummos—Hæc“Get Mony, Mony still! “And then let Virtue follow, if she will.” This, this the saving doctrine, preach'd to all, From Janus summus ab imo Prodocet: hæc recinunt juvenes dictata, senesque,low St. James's up to high St. Paul; From him whose Lævo suspensi loculos tabulamque lacerto. Estquills stand quiver'd at his ear, To him who notches Sticks at Westminster. Barnard in animus tibi, sunt mores, est lingua, fidesque ? Si quadringentis sex, septem millia desint,spirit, sense, and truth abounds. “Pray then what wants he?” fourscore thousand pounds, A Pension, or such Harness for a slave As Bug now has, and Bestia fain would have. Barnard, thou art a Plebs eris ? Cit, with all thy worth; Bestia and Bug, Their Honours, and so forth. Yet every At pueri ludentes, ‘Rex eris (aiunt) “Si recte facies.” Hicchild another song will sing, “Virtue, brave boys! 'tis Virtue makes a King.” True, conscious Honour is to feel no sin, He's arm'd without that's innocent within; Be this thy murus aheneus esto, Nil conscire sibi, nullâ pallescere culpâ!Screen, and this thy Wall of Brass; Compar'd to this, a Minister's an Ass. Roscia, dic sodes, melior lex, an puerorum Nœnia? quæ regnum recte facientibus offert, Et MaribusAnd say, to which shall our applause belong, This new Court jargon, or the good old song? The modern language of corrupted Peers, Or what was spoke at Curiis, & decantata Camillis? Cressy and Poitiers? Isne tibi melius suadet, qui “Rem facias, rem, “Si possis, recte, si non, quocunque modo rem.” UtWho counsels best? who whispers, “Be but Great, “With Praise or Infamy, leave that to fate; “Get Place and Wealth, if possible, with Grace; “If not, by any means get Wealth and Place. For what? to have a proprius spectes lacrymosa Poemata Pupi! An,Box where Eunuchs sing, And foremost in the Circle eye a King. Or qui Fortunæ te responsare superbæ Liberum & erectum,he, who bids thee face with steddy view Proud Fortune, and look shallow Greatness thro': And, præsens hortatur, & aptat?while he bids thee, sets th'Example too? If Quod si me Populus Romanus forte roget, cur Non, utsuch a Doctrine, in St. James's air, Shou'd chance to make the well-drest Rabble stare; If honest S? take scandal at a spark, That less admires the porticibus, sic judiciis fruar iisdem, Nec sequar aut fugiam, quos diligit ipse, vel odit? Olim quodPalace than the Park; Faith I shall give the answer Vulpes ægroto cauta Leoni Respondit, referam: “Quia me vestigia terrent “Omnia te adversum spectantia, nulla retrorsum.Reynard gave, “I cannot like, Dread Sir! your Royal Cave; “Because I see by all the Tracks about, “Full many a Beast goes in, but none comes out.” Adieu to Virtue if you're once a Slave: Send her to Court, you send her to her Grave. Well, if a King's a Lion, at the least The Bellua multorum est capitum, nam quid sequar aut quem? Pars hominum gestitPeople are a many-headed Beast: Can they direct what measures to pursue, Who know themselves so little what to do? Alike in nothing but one Lust of Gold, Just half the land would buy, and half be sold: Their conducere Publica. Sunt quiCountry's wealth our mightier Misers drain, Or cross, to plunder Provinces, the Main: The rest, some farm the Poor-box, some the Pews; Some keep Assemblies, and wou'd keep the Stews; Some Crustis & Pomis, Viduas venentur avaras, Excipiantque Senes quos in vivaria mittunt.with fat Bucks on childless Dotards fawn; Some win rich Widows by their Chine and Brawn; While with the silent growth of ten per Cent, In Dirt and darkness Multis occulto crescit res fœnore ?hundreds stink content. Of all these ways, if each ? Verum Esto, aliis alios rebus, studiisque teneri: Iidem eadem possunt horam durare probantes?pursues his own, Satire be kind, and let the wretch alone. But show me one, who has it in his pow'r To act consistent with himself an hour. Sir Job “Nullus in orbe locus Baiis prelucet amænis:” Si dixit Dives,sail'd forth, the evening bright and still, “No place on earth (he cry'd) like Greenwich hill!” lacus & mare sentit amorem Festinantis heri. Cui siUp starts a Palace, lo! th'obedient base Slopes at its foot, the woods its sides embrace, The silver Thames reflects its marble face. Now let some whimzy, or that vitiosa Libido Fecerit auspicium, cras, “ferramenta Teanum “Tolletis, fabri! ?Dev'l within Which guides all those who know not what they mean But give the Knight (or give his Lady) spleen; “Away, away! take all your scaffolds down, “For Snug's the word: My dear! we'll live in Town.” At am'rous Flavio is the ? Lectus genialis in aula est? Nil ait esse prius, melius nil cælibe vita:Stocking thrown? That very night he longs to lye alone. Si non est, jurat bene solis esse maritis.The Fool whose Wife elopes some thrice a quarter, For matrimonial Solace dies a martyr. Did ever Quo teneam vultus mutantem Protea nodo? QuidProteus, Merlin, any Witch, Transform themselves so strangely as the Rich? “Well, but the pauper? ride: mutatPoor—the Poor have the same itch: They change their tonsores; conductoweekly Barber, weekly News, Prefer a new Japanner to their shoes, Discharge their cænacula, lectos, Balnea,Garrets, move their Beds, and run (They know not whither) in a Chaise and one; They navigio, æquè Nauseat ac locuples, quem ducit priva tirremis.hire their Sculler, and when once aboard, Grow sick, and damn the Climate—like a Lord. Si curtatus inæquali tonsore capillos Occurro, rides; si forte subucula pexæ Trita subest tunicæ, vel si toga dissidet impar, Rides: quid?You laugh, half Beau half Sloven if I stand, My Wig all powder, and all snuff my Band; You laugh, if Coat and Breeches strangely vary, White Gloves, and Linnen worthy Lady Mary! But when mea cum pugnat Sententia secum, Quod petiit, spernit; repetit quod nuper omisit;no Prelate's Lawn with Hair-shirt lin'd, Is half so incoherent as my Mind, When (each Opinion with the next at strife, One Æstuat, & Vitæ disconvenit ordine toto;ebb and flow of follies all my Life) I Diruit, ædificat, mutat quadrata rotundis?plant, root up, I build, and then confound, Turn round to square, and square again to round; Insanire putas solennia me; neque rides, NecYou never change one muscle of your face, You think this Madness but a common case, Nor Medici credis, nec Curatoris egere A Prætore dati? rerumonce to Chanc'ry, nor to The Doctor of Bedlam.Hales apply; Yet hang your lip, to see a Seam awry! Careless how ill I with myself agree; Kind to my dress, my figure, not to Me. Is this my Tutela mearum Cum sis, & pravè sectum stomacheris ob unguem, De te pendentis, te suspicientis, Amici. Ad summam, Sapiens unoGuide, Philosopher, and Friend? This, He who loves me, and who ought to mend? Who ought to make me (what he can, or none,) That Man divine whom Wisdom calls her own, Great without Title, without Fortune bless'd, Rich Dives!ev'n when plunder'd, honoratus!honour'd while oppress'd, Lov'd pulcher! ?without youth, and follow'd without power, At home tho' exil'd, Liber!free, tho' in the Tower. In short, that reas'ning, high, immortal Thing, Just minor est Jove!less than Jove, and ? Rex denique regum! Præcipue sanus ?much above a King, Nay half in Heav'n— ? Nisi cum pituita molesta est.except (what's mighty odd) A Fit of Vapours clouds this Demi-god.
